text.p: Medtronic Inc said Thursday it launched commercial sales in Europe and other markets of its heparin-coated Wiktor GX coronary stent.
The stent was also launched in Australia, as well as in several countries of the Middle East, Latin America and Asia, said the medical devices giant.
A stent is a tiny wire-mesh cylinder designed to be implanted inside human blood vessels to hold them open.
The new Medtronic stent is coated by a process called Hepamed with heparin, a blood-thinning agent that fights clotting and is often used to treat heart patients.
The stent is the world's first heparin-coated stent to attain European regulatory approval and commercial release, Medtronic said.

Coronary stents are increasingly used by cardiologists to support the walls of arteries on the surface of the heart after they have been unclogged with balloon catheters in a procedure known as percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, or PTCA.

Hepamed, developed and patented by Medtronic, is a process that bonds heparin to the surface of the stent. The coating expands with the stent upon deployment and its bonding results in consistent biological activity over time, Medtronic said.
European regulatory approval for the stent was granted in September 1996, for marketing in countries of the European Community, the company said.
